user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SelectFdAdd:
```c
int32 OS_SelectFdAdd(OS_FdSet *Set, osal_id_t objid)
{
    int32        return_code;
    osal_index_t local_id;

    /* check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(Set);

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_STREAM, objid, &local_id);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        /*
         * Sets the bit in the uint8 object_ids array that corresponds
         * to the local_id where local_id >> 3 determines the array element,
         * and the mask/shift sets the bit within that element.
         */
        Set->object_ids[local_id >> 3] |= 1 << (local_id & 0x7);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
OS_CHECK_POINTER(Set);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.8 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: OS_CHECK_POINTER(Set) is a pointer-validation macro that evaluates the parameter but does not assign to it. Evaluating or testing Set (e.g. if (Set == NULL) return ...) does not modify the parameter itself, so this fragment does not violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8. (Note: modifying the object pointed-to via Set->... later in the function is allowed; only assigning to the pointer parameter would violate the rule.)
